references:
Performance with compared baselines.
In Table 1 and Figure 2, we evaluate DP-FedSAM and DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} on EMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets in both settings compared with all baselines from DP-FedAvg to DP-FedAvg-blursblurs\operatorname{blurs}. The baseline methods seem to be overfitting in Table 1, especially on more complex data (e.g., CIFAR-100 in Table 4). The main reasons are the random noise introduced by DP and the over-fitting and inconsistency of the local models. From all these results, it is seen that our proposed algorithms outperform other baselines under symmetric noise both on accuracy and generalization perspectives.
It means that we significantly improve the performance and generate a better trade-off between performance and privacy in DPFL.
For instance, the averaged testing accuracy is 85.90%percent85.9085.90\% in DP-FedSAM and 87.70%percent87.7087.70\% in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} on EMNIST in the IID setting, which are better than other baselines. Meanwhile, the difference between training accuracy and test accuracy is 9.71%percent9.719.71\% in DP-FedSAM and 8.40%percent8.408.40\% in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k}, while that is 17.74%percent17.7417.74\% in DP-FedAvg and 16.41%percent16.4116.41\% in Fed-SMP-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k}, respectively. That means our algorithms significantly mitigate the performance degradation issue caused by DP.

Impact of Non-IID levels.
In the experiments under different participation cases as shown in Table 1, we further prove the robust generalization of the proposed algorithms. Heterogeneous data distribution of local clients is set to various participation levels from IID, Dirichlet 0.6, and Dirichlet 0.3, which makes the training of the global model more difficult. On EMNIST, as the Non-IID level decreases, DP-FedSAM achieves better generalization than DP-FedAvg, and the difference between training accuracy and test accuracy in DP-FedSAM {19.47%,10.75%,9.71%}percent19.47percent10.75percent9.71\{19.47\%,10.75\%,9.71\%\} are lower than that in DP-FedAvg {26.18%,17.35%,17.74%}percent26.18percent17.35percent17.74\{26.18\%,17.35\%,17.74\%\}. Similarly, the difference values in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} {17.50%,11.07%,8.40%}percent17.50percent11.07percent8.40\{17.50\%,11.07\%,8.40\%\} are also lower than that in Fed-SMP-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} {23.56%,16.31%,16.41%}percent23.56percent16.31percent16.41\{23.56\%,16.31\%,16.41\%\}. These observations confirm that our algorithms are more robust than baselines in various degrees of heterogeneous data.

Performance under different privacy budgets ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.
Table 2 shows the test accuracies for the different level privacy guarantees. Note that ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is not a hyper-parameter, but can be obtained by the privacy design in each round such as Eq. (13).
Our methods consistently outperform the previous SOTA methods under various privacy budgets ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.
Specifically, DP-FedSAM and DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} significantly improve the accuracy of DP-FedAvg and Fed-SMP-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} by 1%∼4%similar-topercent1percent41\%\sim 4\% and 3%∼4%similar-topercent3percent43\%\sim 4\% under the same ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, respectively.
Furthermore, the test accuracy can improve as the privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon increases, which suggests us a better balance is necessary between training performance and privacy. There is a better trade-off when achieving better accuracy under the same ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon or a smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon under approximately the same accuracy.

Performance with compared baselines.
In Table 1 and Figure 2, we evaluate DP-FedSAM and DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} on EMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets in both settings compared with all baselines from DP-FedAvg to DP-FedAvg-blursblurs\operatorname{blurs}. The baseline methods seem to be overfitting in Table 1, especially on more complex data (e.g., CIFAR-100 in Table 4). The main reasons are the random noise introduced by DP and the over-fitting and inconsistency of the local models. From all these results, it is seen that our proposed algorithms outperform other baselines under symmetric noise both on accuracy and generalization perspectives.
It means that we significantly improve the performance and generate a better trade-off between performance and privacy in DPFL.
For instance, the averaged testing accuracy is 85.90%percent85.9085.90\% in DP-FedSAM and 87.70%percent87.7087.70\% in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} on EMNIST in the IID setting, which are better than other baselines. Meanwhile, the difference between training accuracy and test accuracy is 9.71%percent9.719.71\% in DP-FedSAM and 8.40%percent8.408.40\% in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k}, while that is 17.74%percent17.7417.74\% in DP-FedAvg and 16.41%percent16.4116.41\% in Fed-SMP-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k}, respectively. That means our algorithms significantly mitigate the performance degradation issue caused by DP.

In Table 4 and Figure 5, we evaluate DP-FedSAM and DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} on CIFAR-100 dataset in both settings compared with all baselines from DP-FedAvg to DP-FedAvg-blursblurs\operatorname{blurs}. From all these results, it is clearly seen that our proposed algorithms outperform other baselines under symmetric noise both on accuracy and generalization perspectives. It means that we significantly improve the performance and generate a better trade-off between performance and privacy in DPFL.
For instance, in the IID setting, the averaged testing accuracy is 20.64%percent20.6420.64\% in DP-FedSAM, where the accuracy gain is 3.17%percent3.173.17\% compared with DP-FedAvg.
And the average testing accuracy is 22.30%percent22.3022.30\% in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k},
where the accuracy gain is 3.21%percent3.213.21\% compared with Fed-SMP-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k}.
That means our algorithms significantly mitigate the performance degradation issue caused by DP.

Under different participation cases as shown in Table 4, we further prove the robust generalization of the proposed algorithms. Heterogeneous data distribution of local clients is set to various participation levels from IID, Dirichlet 0.6, and Dirichlet 0.3, which makes the training of the global model more difficult.
For instance, compared with DP-FedAvg on CIFAR-100, the test accuracy gain in DP-FedSAM is {2.78%,3.17%,3.17%}percent2.78percent3.17percent3.17\{2.78\%,3.17\%,3.17\%\}. Meanwhile, the test accuracy gain in DP-FedSAM-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k} is {2.27%,3.17%,3.21%}percent2.27percent3.17percent3.21\{2.27\%,3.17\%,3.21\%\} compared with Fed-SMP-topksubscripttop𝑘\operatorname{top}_{k}.
These observations confirm that our algorithms are more robust than baselines in various degrees of heterogeneous data.
